content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the length \(l_0\), in cm, of the spring without any load
On Fig. 1.2 measure the stretched length \(l_1\), in cm
Calculate the extension \(e_1\) of the spring using the equation \(e_1 = (l_1 - l_0)\)
Determine a value for \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{m}{e_1}\), where \(m = 100 \text{g}\)
He then places a metal block \(\mathbf{X}\) with its centre at the \(40.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
Explain briefly how the student can make sure that the block is in the correct position. You may wish to use a diagram
The student measures the new length \(l_{3}\) of the spring and records it as
Determine the change in the extension \(\mathsf{e}_{2}\) due to block \(\mathbf{X}\), using the equation \(\mathsf{e}_{2} = (l_{3} - l_{2})\)
Calculate the mass \(M\) of block \(\mathbf{X}\) using your answers to (a)(iv) and (b)(ii) and the equation \(M = k\left(\frac{\Theta_2}{0.40}\right)\)
The apparatus is then set up as shown in Fig. 1.3
The rule is at a small angle to the bench
A student measures the length of the stretched spring and obtains the result
Suggest two practical causes of inaccuracy in this experiment
An IGCSE class is carrying out this experiment to determine the mass of a metal blo
Fig. 1.1 shows a spring drawn full size
Fig. 1.2, also full size, shows the spring with a load of \(100\mathrm{g}\) suspended from it

Determine which surface, white or black, absorbs thermal radiation more efficiently. State the experimental evidence for your choice
surface
evidence
A student suggests that the rate of temperature rise will be greater at the beginning of the experiment than towards the end of the experiment
State whether the results support this. Justify your answer with reference to the data for black card
statement
justification
The lamp is switched on and the temperature recorded every minute
After 300s, the lamp is switched off and the white card is replaced with a piece of black card
Another IGCSE student wants to repeat the experiment

Suggest one precaution which she should take with the apparatus to make the comparison between white and black surfaces a fair one. Explain why not taking this precaution might cause the test to be unfair
precaution
explanation
Some IGCSE students have been asked to investigate how different surfaces absorb radiation
The apparatus is set up as shown in Fig. 2.1, with a piece of white card in close contact with the thermometer bulb
The distance between the card and the lamp is \(1.0 \text{cm}\)
Fig. 2.1 shows the reading on the thermometer before the lamp is switched on
Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 3.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter correctly connected to measure the potential difference across the lamp
Complete the column headings in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in the table, the resistance \(R\) of the lamp at each potential
difference \(V\) using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Table 3.1 shows the values of potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) obtained during the experiment, and observations regarding the lamp

table.html:
\(V/\)\(I/\)\(R/\)observation
1.50.15lamp is just glowing
3.20.23lamp is lit but is dim
4.70.26lamp is brighter
6.50.31lamp is very bright

content.text: A student suggests that the resistance of a lamp stays the same whatever its temperature
State whether the results support this idea. Justify your answer, using the results and the observations obtained during the experiment
statement
justification
The IGCSE class is investigating the resistance of a lamp
The apparatus has been set out as shown in Fig. 3.1
Measure the object distance \(u\) on Fig. 4.1
Measure the image distance \(v\) on Fig. 4.1
The diagram is drawn to \(\frac{1}{5}^{\text{th}}\) full size. Determine the actual values, in metres, of \(u\) and \(v\). Record these values in Table 4.1
The object distance \(u\) is set and a sharp image is obtained on the screen
Four more object distances are set up and these and the corresponding image distances are recorded in Table 4.1
Complete the table by calculating values of \(\frac{1}{u}\) and \(\frac{1}{v}\) as necessary
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{\nu}\Big/ \frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((y\text{-axis})\) against \(\frac{1}{u}\Big/ \frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((x\text{-axis})\). Begin both axes at the origin
The scale must allow the best-fit line, when extended beyond the range of the data, cross both axes
From the graph, determine the value \(p\) of \(\frac{1}{u}\) when \(\frac{1}{v}\) is zero (the \(x\)-intercept)
From the graph, determine the value \(q\) of \(\frac{1}{v}\) when \(\frac{1}{u}\) is zero (the \(y\)-intercept)
Calculate \(z\), where \(z\) is the average value of \(p\) and \(q\)
z =

An IGCSE class is carrying out an experiment to determine the focal length of a con lens
The apparatus is set up as shown in Fig. 4.1
One student drops the ball several times from a height of \(100\mathrm{cm}\). Each time he measures the height to which the ball bounces. His measurements are shown in Table 5.1
Explain how a valid average value for the height of the bounce could be achieved from these results. You are not asked to calculate it
Another student releases the ball from a height of \(100 \text{cm}\) on to a stone floor. It to a height of \(75 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the efficiency of the bounce on the stone floor using the equation
efficiency = \(\frac{\text{height of bounce}}{\text{height of release}} \times 100\%\)
efficiency =   .........
A third student releases the ball from a height of \(85 \text{cm}\) on to a concrete floor and it bounces to a height of \(75 \text{cm}\)
Without any further calculation, state whether the efficiency for the concrete floor is less than, greater than, or roughly the same as the efficiency for the stone floor. Explain your reasoning
statement
explanation
Some IGCSE students are carrying out an experiment to investigate how a tennis bounce on various surfaces
Fig. 5.1 shows how they are doing this. The ball is dropped from a known height and the height of the bounce is measured
